Award.AbstractNarration:
NSF Proposal 1702979 - Doctoral Dissertation Research:

Title: The Legacies of Vagrancy Law in Contemporary Homelessness Regulation

PI: Matthew Marr
Co-PI: Rayna Rusenko

Studies examining new initiatives in twenty-first century regulation of homelessness tend to center on advanced Western contexts. They focus on either the significance of contemporary neoliberal ideas or on policy histories. Over the last decade, Japanese and Malaysian government agencies have enacted new policing, shelter, and housing initiatives to achieve zero homelessness. This project will investigate contemporary homelessness regulation in two capital cities in the Asian region;namely, Tokyo, Japan, and Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. It will examine how homelessness regulations are rooted in the historical development of each nation's welfare and penal systems, thereby giving attention to post/metropolitan and post/colonial contexts. The project will use a global historical lens to inform interdisciplinary literature on neoliberal governance, homelessness regulation, and legacies of imperial and colonial politico-legal cultures.
By analyzing key shifts in homelessness regulation across two distinct developmental contexts in Asia, this investigation will advance understanding of the influences of particular state forms and their respective penal and welfare infrastructures with regard to homelessness management. In addition, the project will identify the influences of cross-border networks in the adoption, transformation, and exchange of globally-mobile ideas and practices relating to homelessness regulation in the Asian region. Such investigation is critical for understanding the distinct local forms of contemporary policy regimes, as well as broader cross-border innovations and inter-relations, particularly in light of shared global histories of vagrancy laws and related policy networks.

This project will illustrate how current trends in homelessness policy tap into historically-established institutional arrangements and their ideational underpinnings, thereby driving unique policy variations and individual street-level experiences. This project includes the use of comparative historical and ethnographic methods to examine shifts in homelessness regulation in two sites from the late-nineteenth century to the present. The investigator will identify key historical shifts in ideas and institutions underpinning contemporary organization through archival research and interviews, and trace street-level impacts of policy through archival ethnography and ethnographic fieldwork. This project, by its focus on Asian cities of varied developmental statuses, seeks to answer questions regarding historical continuities and breaks in global and local trajectories of homelessness regulation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Rayna Rusenko has completed research for her dissertation “The Legacies of Vagrancy Law in Contemporary Homelessness Regulation: A Comparative Historical Examination of Tokyo, Japan and Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia” supported by the NSF Dissertation Improvement Grant. During her finding period she spent seven months in Tokyo, Japan and six months in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia conducting archival research and ethnographic fieldwork. As a sociologist of law and public policy, Rusenko is interested in identifying the role that homelessness regulation has in propagating, or ameliorating, structural inequalities underlying the persistence of homelessness, with attention to (post)colonial and (post)imperial contexts. She takes a distinctly broad view of homelessness regulation to consider criminal justice, welfare, civic registration, and urban development policies that authorize interventions by governmental and quasi-governmental agencies. By interrogating government responses to homelessness, she directs attention to how people experiencing homelessness are systematically barred from full legal personhood and, by extension, access to social and political rights and material resources.

Rusenko’s research underscores the significance of legacies of empire in contemporary homelessness regulation in Kuala Lumpur, Malay(si)a and Tokyo, Japan. Specifically, she adopts a global historical lens as she considers the legal and organizational structure of homelessness regulation in each city from their mid-nineteenth century integration into the world economy. During archival research, Rusenko achieved her goal of identifying the locally-situated ways in which homelessness has been (re)constructed over time as a problem of social and spatial disorder, defined differently across each city’s raced, gendered and otherwise hierarchically-ordered (post)colonial and (post)imperial contexts. This policy construction upholds what she identifies as the legacy of vagrancy law: a delegitimization of homelessness across multiple policy fields, rendering it grounds for criminalization, eviction, public assistance disqualification, and political disenfranchisement, among other things. Through ethnographic fieldwork, Rusenko found that recent policy innovations, including welfarist approaches, incorporate terms constraining the socio-political rights and socio-spatial mobility of people targeted by policy, justified through legal frameworks that deem homelessness to be an illegitimate—and, hence, unprotected—status. Viewed together, Rusenko’s findings underscore how the delegitimization of homeless existence across multiple policy fields propagates socio-political exclusion of persons experiencing homelessness, which, in turn, poses problems not only for resolving homelessness but for democratic governance itself. 

Rusenko’s fieldwork also had impacts beyond data collection. In Tokyo, she helped organize meetings for a community facing eviction to consult with legal experts and non-government organizations. In Kuala Lumpur, she connected people seeking aid with non-government and government services. In addition, she contributed to a Japanese counter-mapping project dedicated to archiving and publicly distributing data on evictions and other impacts of the Tokyo 2020 Olympics on urban poor neighborhoods and communities.

Rusenko’s research in Tokyo and Kuala Lumpur forms the basis of her dissertation to be completed in 2020. The dissertation is an important contribution to sociology because it asserts the extent to which legacies of empire pervade policy science, and how policy regimes governing homelessness reproduce intrinsically anti-democratic ideologies and institutions by nullifying the social and political legitimacy of unsheltered existence itself. Rusenko’s intervention asserts that addressing homelessness effectively requires its full legalization and formal recognition as not an aberration but an unexceptional variation in modern distributions of wealth and power.
